Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Rachael Tomasino of the University of Denver to conduct a research project, entitled "Removing anomalies from images of planetary nebula," during the summer of 2012 at the Japanese Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA), Institute of Space and Astronautical Science (ISAS) in Sagamihara. The host scientist is Dr. Yamamura Issei.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is improve visualization tools for the study of stellar ejecta, critical to understanding the evolution and circulation of matter in the Universe as a whole. Understanding stellar mass loss is synonymous with understanding the primary means to distribute matter synthesized in stars into the surrounding space as the seed for the following generations of stars, planets, and, ultimately, life. The research focuses on generating the cleanest maps of circumstellar dust shells by using interactive software named FAST (Far-infrared surveyor AKARI Slow-scan Tools) to optimize the images generated when data are reduced using a process known as AKARI MLHES (excavating Mass Loss History in Extended dust shells of Evolved Stars). This procedure optimizes the observational characterization of the history of stellar mass loss.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to learn about possible processing of stellar ejecta, which is expanding as the circumstellar shells and upon passing the interface regions to the interstellar medium (ISM), which is critical to understanding the evolution/circulation of matter in the Universe as a whole. Understanding stellar mass loss is synonymous with understanding the primary means to distribute matter that is synthesized in stars into the surrounding space as the seed for the next generations of stars, planets, and, ultimately, life. The research focused on generating the cleanest maps of the circumstellar dust shells by using the very interactive software, FAST (Far-­?infrared surveyor AKARI Slow-­?scan Tools), to reduce the AKARI MLHES (excavating Mass Loss History in Extended dust shells of Evolved Stars) data so that the observational characterization of the history of stellar mass loss is done optimally. This work also provided necessary feedback about the interface of the FAST program along with finding glitches. This feedback will be incorportated in future updates to make the program more robust and userfriendly.

The Broader Impacts of this EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-­?hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. The results from this fellowship have already been presented at the  Laboratory of Infrared Astrophysics Seminar, in Sagamihara, Japan in August 2012 and at the American Physics Society’s Four Corners Regional Meeting in Socorro, NM on October 26, 2012. Future presentations include sharing this reserach with the local Denver community through the University of Denver’s Office of News and Public Affairs and giving talks at the historical Chamberlin Observatory. The findings will also be shared globally through AAS meetings, other field-­?specific conferences and through press releases at ISAS, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan (NAOJ) and the Astronomical Society of Japan.
